reviewText: What a bold and beautiful film that director Yann Samuell has created.  Rivaling that of the French hit Amelie, this film proves that creativity and emotion can go hand in hand.  From the opening scenes until the final tearjerker, I was glued to the screen.  I was immersed into all the characters as well as the situations around them.  This is a love story to the tenth degree.  Samuell spectacularly takes all genre's of film and cut and pastes them into Jeux d'enfants.  This was a collage of fierce color and intense cinematography.  It kept you grounded on your couch yet somehow took you to new levels of the world.  His use of color, imaginative storytelling, and mastery behind the camera helped this film go from average love story to a clear representation of human emotion.  To say the least, this film was perfect.To begin, Samuell hands us two of the freshest actors to play the parts of Julien and Sophie.  Unknown in American cinema, these two build that chemistry that most of the time Hollywood money cannot buy.  From the moment they met at the bus stop, until the very ending scenes, we could tell that they were in love.  There was no question in my mind that these two were perfect together, and what helped this development occur is the two actors that portrayed them.  Their ability to control each other and also the camera was impressive.  They played off each other so well that I had to remind myself that this was a fictional film, not a documentary.  This amazing acting allowed me to grow attached to the characters from the beginning of the film until the end.  There was not a singular scene where I felt they were in it just to collect the money.  You could tell that they were excited about this film and it brightly shown through the screen.Samuell not only takes two actors to tell his story, but also he gives them a cartoon-esque world to grow in.  From the opening scene with the bus, we are shown this imaginative world similar to a fairy tale.  Rules in this world are different than ours, yet it is still our Earth.  That is what helps us keep grounded during this story.  Some of the dares are outlandish, yet we believe them because of this world that Samuell has created and the characters he has picked for us.  The different uses of camera work help build the overall tone of the film.  Samuell teeters on the edge of too comical and childish, but never falls.  You are constantly reminded throughout this film that it is an adult story, not for children.  Yet, there are colors and images that will no doubtably evoke memories from your youth throughout this film.  That is an important part of this film.  This is the story of two people that never grow up.  They rely on this game to keep their spirits alive, and it is through this game that they fall in love.  This film reminded me of what it would be like to film an adult version of freeze-tag.  He has taken a childhood game ("dare") and given us an adult spin.This film impressed me.  The colors that Samuell uses to help heighten the emotion of these two characters and build a very surreal world for us are enjoyable everytime I watch this film.  He knows what he is doing with this film, and does not hold back at all.  Just as you think that you have these characters figured out, he forces them apart, forcing us to grow fonder for them to reunite.  This is nothing more than a film about Julien and Sophie, and while so many times we loose focus of these types of characters when creative cinematography comes into place, it never happens with this film.  Samuell is a genius and presents to us a very beautiful story about love. The clever uses of many cover versions of "La Vie en Rose" will have you humming the song as this film comes to a close.  I have read reviews that say it is nothing like Amelie, and I couldn't agree with them more.  This is not Amelie, this is its own film with a completely different story, style, and theme.  This film honorably stands on its own two feet and walks with the greatest of ease.  I suggest this film to everyone who is looking for that creative story about love and games.Grade: ***** out of *****
Title: N/A

reviewText: Love Me If You Dare would be an excellent first date movie for a pair of 20 year olds - the protagonists are attractive, it's pretty to watch, charming in an offbeat, whacky way, and fiercely determined to perpetuate the preposterous mythology of romantic love people in this age bracket hold dear.  It is like an exquisite souffle, light and delicious but lacking content or nutritional value worthy of the name.The picture runs entirely on one small but effective gadget.  Two kids, boy and girl, with different emotional handicaps, play a game of "dare" which functions like a narcotic in that it allows them to escape reality.  As they grow older the game takes on a life of its own; precisely when the two of them should be outgrowing juvenile pastimes the game itself becomes an adult, forcing them to remain children.  Masquerading as grown-ups they use the "game" to hurt each other with real cruelty, squander large chunks of their lives, and muck about with the emotions of others along the way.This, of course, is what is actually happening.  However, the film is so darn good-natured and cute, that this obsessive infantilism seems charming and, well, just plain French.  The omnipresent carousel candy tin is quick to remind us that all romantic relationships have an element of "game" in them, and that lovers frequently play high stakes "dare" games with one another that are not nearly so cute.  In this respect one can almost see content in Love Me If You Dare, but one must holds one's pince-nez close to the screen for it to appear.When you are close to forgiving this film's many sins and embracing it as charming fluff, it hits you in the face with one of the most appalling endings in the history of cinema.  Our pair of 20 year olds on their first date may be swooning with the sheer poetic symbolism of it all, however, all others will be reminded that often love is not merely blind, it is also breathtakingly stupid.

reviewText: The U.S. trailers presented "Love Me If You Dare" as fluffy, dreamy "Amelie"-like French froth.  Check out the marketing tagline foisted upon us: "From the visionary mind of director Yann Samuell comes France's hit comedy!" (The exclamation point is the marketers').  Sounds like a real bowl of hearty yuks.Don't believe that for a second: As its two protagonists become adults, "Dare" turns increasingly darker and mean-spirited, topped off with an ending that can only be categorized as revolting.  We're meant, I guess, to interpret the final action of Julien and Sophie as a sign of the their eternal love for each other.  All I could think about was their extreme selfishness.Marion Cotillard, so enchanting in 'Big Fish', looks great here and deserves a bigger U.S. audience.  She and cinematographer Antoine Roch (the look of the film is mesmerizing) are far and away the standouts.

reviewText: Note: French with English subtitles.`Love Me If You Dare' released in '04 is one of the weirdest films I've watched in a long time.  Like most unsuspecting viewers unfamiliar with the storyline of this film, I imagined it would be something light and enjoyable, you know an upbeat, feel good French romance. Well be forewarned, it's nothing of the kind.Synopsis: Two children with a less than perfect home life , Julien (Guillaume Canet) and Sophie (Marion Cotillard), become best friends who never outgrow their childish game of dare which they refer to as "game". The game takes precedence over everything in life; parents, wives, husbands, children, school, jobs, everything.  Their inability to function outside the parameters of this addictive competition leads them on a course of action the definitely takes their desire for each other to an extreme and unexpected conclusion.Critique: What started out as a rather odd but somewhat charming tale of childhood silliness degenerates into a rather nasty story of obsessive, compulsive behavior that is not only difficult to watch but pointless to sit through as their narcissistic game ruins not only their own lives but the lives of the people around them as well. Even the lovely Marion Cotillard can't save this tragic, amoral tale of self absorption.My Rating: Obviously no recommendation here, -2  Stars-.
summary: "How We Won The Game" ~ When Game Becomes Life And Life Merely Intermission

reviewText: I freaking love this movie and have ever since I saw it! Thrilled to have found it at a reasonable price since my old DVD copy has since worn out, this edition is an import from Latin America so it has Spanish subtitles or a French language only option so if you're fluent in Spanish like me and have been searching for this movie that's since been out of print in the United States: Highly Recommended Buy if you're into unconventional and twisted love stories. This movie is not your typical boy meets girl and they live happily ever after story, in fact the "childish games" Julien and Sophie play are at times quite out there and morbid, if I knew a Julien and Sophie in real life I would probably tell them to Grow Up in more colorful language, but this being a movie I suspend disbelief since to me it has always been a quirky, charming tale. Guillaume Canet and Marion Cotillard have great chemistry so to me it was no surprise to discover that they are a real life couple. All in all the movie and special features are wonderful and no cause for complaints.

reviewText: I was drawn to this movie from seeing the preview. It looked as if it was filled with mystical realism and an original plot. I needed to see this movie.It pulls you in with the two children, one crying on the street with her papers strewn about, the other: letting the schoolbus roll while the bus driver is helping the little girl. The students who tortured her roll down the street, screaming out of the back window. Let the game begin.They pass the tin can back and forth given to Julien by his dying mother, and the person who holds it must decide the dare. It can range from the very simple (wearing your undergarments on the OUTSIDE of your clothes) to difficult (standing on a train track with a blindfold, while a train is coming.)I enjoyed the whole idea of it. They were obsessed, with the game and with each other. The older they got, the more serious it became. Not only that, but they hurt each other, emotionally, over and over. (Hence the subject line.) If you are looking for a simple, happy love story, you are looking in the wrong place. This is dark and sad at times, with an ending that leaves you guessing.I think that the reason I scored it a little lower than the highest rating, was because once they became adults, it seemed to be the same thing over and over. One chases after the other, he/she runs away. Rinse, repeat. Unrequited love can get repetitive. I could handle the fact that both of them weren't very likeable characters. They were willing to throw everything away (and did) for each other, and this "game."Often compared to Amelie, I would say that this is similiar in style, but lacks in the "glass half full" attitude.If you are interested in deviating from the norm, I would recommend it. Just don't expect it to leave you with a warm, fuzzy feeling inside.

reviewText: It's a revealing moment when Sergei Nimovitch groans that "something is stabbing [him] in the back" and digs the carousel-tin out of the couch cushion. When he lovingly mutters that it's Sophie's "teddy" and she replies with the above line, we know that love (for Sophie) is not soft and gentle but hard and painful. And the "stabbing in the back" bit ... priceless.Yann Samuell breaks "Jeux d'enfants" into four segments: "Game," "Set," "Match," and "Dares of Dares." The segments grow progressively darker when puckish pranks turn to sadistic challenges. These plotted, breathtaking moments become nearly impossible to watch ... and since the viewer is frequently aligned with the "victim," Sophie/Julien's surprise becomes her/his. But, (and here's the ingenuity of the piece) there really are no "victims," per se. Both Sophie and Julien are broken individuals (one the child of destitute Polish immigrants and the other contending with the death of his mother). Unlike most romances, they do not provide healing support for each other ... instead, they opt to hurt and humiliate the other. Nonetheless, in the end, the dynamic of their relationship becomes clear: what began as a portrait of mean-spirited dysfunction matures into "something else" ... many will find the actual conclusion shocking (though it shouldn't be), so I'll stop here.The cinematography is a treat for viewers. Super-saturated colors allow for a playful read to otherwise tense scenes. Brilliant. Moreover, the casting is lovely. American viewers may note the boyish-charm of Noah Wyle in Guillaume Canet. And yes, for some, these characters may prove beyond comprehension; however, many may see shards of themselves in these two. Finally, the clever bookends (should) prepare the viewer for the conclusion ... smart move.Yann Samuell's film is dark, hurtful, and potentially unsatisfying (depending on your idea of "romance"). With that said, the absolute brutality of this piece is why I feel compelled to recommend it. Bombarded by saccharine films likeThe NotebookandA Walk to Remember, I'm ready for romantic films with a little more "bite." And, I assure you, Samell delivers.

reviewText: JEUX D'ENFANTS is a delectable pastry of a movie that puffs with imagination and surrealism and joy.  Why this confection was given the translated title of LOVE ME IF YOU DARE begs credibility  as the entire story is about "Children's Games"!Julien (Thibault Vehaeghe as a child/Guillaume Canet as a young man/Robert Willar as an old man) and Sophie (Josephine Lebas-Joly as a child/Marion Cotillard as a young girl/Nathalie Natier as an old woman) share a game they created as children to make their otherwise rather grim lives bearable: the game consists of one challenging the other to do something outrageous, the talisman for the game being a beautifully decorated candy canister passed to the challenged one during the game. When the  dare is accomplished, the canister is passed back and the challenged person announces "Game!".Through the first portion of the film the games are funny and a bit bizarre (the actors playing Julien and Sophie as children are extraordinary!).  Time passes and the two part ways but as adults continue the games.  The manner in which these games result in the futures of Julien and Sophie is the adult version and again acted with finesse and brio.  Revealing the ending would spoil the fun, though part of the joy of this film is the fact that the ending is left to the imagination of individual viewers.The color photography is a delight, the score suits the atmosphere, and Director Yann Samuel manages to find just the right balance between farce, tender love stories, and fantasy, making the final impact as fresh as champagne.  No wonder this was such a success in France.. In French with subtitles.  Grady Harp, November 2004.

reviewText: This movie was really good in the beginning...hence the two stars.  The story revolves around two children who have a rough life, one is a cast out in school who also lives in low income housing.  The boy is losing his mother to cancer.  It is a very sad situation, and the children who play these characters are adorable.  They were by far the best part of this movie, hence the two stars.  The children dare each other to do insane things to get past their sadness, however, as they grow up, they don't mature whatsoever.  They still act as though they are seven years old.  The things that they do will boggle your mind, and you'll wonder how they haven't been locked away yet.  The whole story itself just completely gets out of control and becomes so unbelievable, you have to watch just to see how crazy it can actually get...and take my word for it, it's nuts.  The bad part about that is...it was meant to be taken seriously.  This film was just not worth the hour and a half it took to watch it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Many people will comment that movie is reminiscent of Amelie with its poetic vision and love-able characters. Many probably don't realize that the writer started this piece 2 years before Amelie hit the screen. Whatever the case, this is a beautiful piece which portrays love lasting throughout time in a thoughtful, ingenious way...Jeux d'enfants" tells us the friendship & love story of Julien and Sophie (Guillaume Canet and Marion Cotillard who are fantastic) since their childhood."Jeux d'enfants" tells what makes the childhood wonderful: freedom, innocence, imagination, unconditional love... Instead of facing their (terrible) problems in life, young Julien and Sophie choose to create a game and make bets that are more and more daring, crazy...and funny. They grow up and game continues. Until when?This movie is a fantasy about escape, about the will to play, and then not being unhappy, at any cost. In the movie Julien told us that this game is his drug and this fairy tale, from its beginning to its wonderful and touching ending, is also about this dependency.I can say easily that this movie is without a doubt one of the most amazing films I've seen this year. It excellently blended so many genres of films, from the dark comedic aspect to the romantic love story that most people know the French for. However, to add on to that, the cinematography and actors certainly didn't hurt the movie. The style of the movie was gorgeous and radiant in it's depiction of emotions, that we often see conveyed in the color scheme of the environment. For example, in an especially romantic scene, the frame is filled with deep purples and passionate reds, colors that seem to strengthen the emotion. How you feel about the ending, and the characters, will be determined by your view of romantic love. Either way, it's a hard movie to forget!
summary: This is one dark yet playful comedy...... and O' I'm Game!

reviewText: I saw a preview of `Love Me If You Dare' while I was about to watch another flick with two girl friends, and it was so compelling that I immediately stopped watching that movie to hunt for Love Me If You Dare in local movie stores.This movie did not disappoint our expectations; this movie is easily my second favorite movie of all time (next to Almost Famous) and my favorite romance movie of all time.  I show it to every friend or acquaintance at every possible opportunity; I've bought roughly six copies of this DVD and given four of them out.The love relationship of Julien and Sophie is passionate, intense, and destructive, but in the end it is very touching.  Growing up together, they form a true bond of friendship in a chaotic atmosphere.  They are broken and haphazard with their emotions, which bring this movie together in a perfect way to relate that love is not chic; the stars rarely align to form that perfect attraction-to-relationship time span that encompasses all of two weeks.  Julien and Sophie's love takes years, and that's where the true beauty sets in.The end of this movie will cause disarray and contemplation on its meaning, leaving open to interpretation to yourself and amongst friends what eternal love is all about and the fates of Julien and Sophie.  Not everyone will agree or like the ending, but I encourage you to give it a second and third watch; each time I see this movie, I come to different conclusions about life, love, and relationships.  This is what makes Love Me If You Dare such a spectacular movie.
summary: Watch This Movie, Gap or No Gap?

reviewText: This French import shows the essential differences in sensibility between European and American cinema. The story follows two Parisians, Julien and Sophie, from their first meeting as children through adulthood as they "game" each other with stunts and dares.The English title tells you a lot about their relationship and the goings-on in this film, which takes place through one of the busiest scripts I've followed in months. Hardly a second goes by in this movie without someone saying something in rapid machine gun fashion. Be prepared to dedicate yourself to subtitles before you watch the English language version!What astounded me most in this film is how the French use children in ways that seem nearly abusive to conservative Americans. One scene where young elementary school children are asked to list words beginning with "B" chides moralitst viewers with children spewing forth not profanity but sexual innuendo and sex acts. That's the difference between European and American cinema, I suppose.This movie is clearly above average and is compelling thoughout its 85 minute span. You follow the characters through about 75 years of life in times that are filled with curiosity, elation, humor and heartbreak. The games are indicated by a tin the couple passes back and forth throughout the film.As a viewer, you may be baffled some of the time and you will surely be rewarded for hanging in there when you aren't sure what's happening. The movie is more a landscape than a narrative and your rewards for traversing that landscape are great.

reviewText: After the success of "Amelie," the Hollywood marketing machine is in desperate search of the next big foreign romantic comedy and likewise misleads the public by packaging every movie to come out of France as the sequel to "Amelie."  "Love Me if You Dare" is very much a romantic BLACK comedy, a fact that will likely turn off viewers who come in strictly with an "Amelie" mindset.  Don't, and I think you'll really appreciate what THIS movie has to offer, which is a charm all its own.  For those of you unsure of what to expect from a romantic black comedy, think "Secretary" but without the S&M.;I was really pleasantly surprised by this movie because I loved "Amelie" and hated "Secretary," yet I thoroughly enjoyed this movie.  The story of two people so obviously in love with each other yet so wrong for each other turns the romantic comedy archetype on its head.  And it's not just the typical "he/she is from the wrong side of the tracks" storyline although that plays a part.  There are SO many reasons why Sophie and Julien should not be together, so much so that in any other movie you would end up hating one or both characters, but you can't help but like and want them to be together.  It's so cheesy to say "Oh, they're soulmates" but they are and it's not a neat, pretty package.  I love how this movie explores that idea because it shows everything that goes along with love - jealously, anger, bitterness, passion, and even hatred.  It's messy and it can be dark, but it's also the most exhilarating, undiminished thing in your life.Don't be turned off by my review - it's not all dark.  There are enough moments of whimsy to satisfy the most avid "Amelie"-lover out there.  Some moments will make you laugh out loud.  And some moments will make you blanch.  But it's love in all its guts and glory.  "Love Me if You Dare" adds some much needed edginess and originality to the current stream of banal and redundant romantic comedies.  "Amelie" was wonderful but give this movie the chance it deserves.
summary: Don't Compare to Amelie and Enjoy It For What It Is

reviewText: Yann Samuel's film "Love Me if you Dare" ("Jeux d'Enfants") charts the course of two misfits (Guillaume Canet and Marion Cotillard) who create a private game of Dare as children that becomes more complex and absurd as both enter into adulthood.The production is gorgeous with Samuel using light and in particular color, or the lack of them as a way of conveying mood and emotion. Also, the two leads: Canet and Cotillard are charming in a warped, out-of-kilter way. Ultimately though the hyper emotionality and the complex relationship between the two leads defeats Samuel and we walk away from the film feeling cheated and spent.Samuel tries to keep a rein on the ever-escalating action but it spins out of control into mean-spirited ugliness nonetheless. Childhood games are (remember that in France this film was called "Jeux d'enfants" or Child's Games) better left behind in childhood, carried over into adulthood they quickly turn into sadism.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jeux d'Enfants, the film's French title, tells us what this is right off the bat. Games of children, children's games. The English title, Love Me If You Dare, is misleading. It is not a love story in that sense, but a story of pathology: these two people never outgrow their game, one that begins in childhood and which entraps the two protagonists in a sub-adulthood, an immaturity neither can escape. The game, once begun, becomes the only world in which these two children can express themselves, and thus the game itself becomes a trap. And because these two players cannot see their way out of it, they are doomed to play it to the end, and thus, psychologically, never to escape the brightly-colored chains of childhood. That is both the appeal and the revulsion some feel towards it. The protagonists, Julien and Sophie, become addicted to the game and keep playing it - because of their inabililty to come together on a more adult level - as a means of connecting, and staying connected, to one another. They are clearly in love but are forced to remain unable to make the transition that we all have to make if we ever hope to grow and to grow up. Even the ending - which I will not give away here - represents this pathological viewpoint.The remarks by some that these two have no empathy with others is quite correct. They can't. They are stuck. As children will, they see only themselves and their own universe, and if they hurt others with their game it is precisely the way children do that very thing: they don't have empathy beyond their own walls. They are all that matters in the world, just they two. All else is just backdrop for the game. Seen in this way, the movie is quite brilliant. But if you are looking for a real love story where people learn and grow, even if they ultimately do separate, this is not your movie.I purposely did not rent this because I didn't want to sit through what looked like one long exercise in some clever and irritating sado-masochism. But I saw it on the Sundance Channel and have to say that I was pleasantly surprised because I was able to completely revise my idea of what this was and, therefore, enjoy it more than I expected I would. It was not like any of the professional reviews I read at all. If we were to try and know these two, to be friends with them, we would throw up our hands in despair. They would enrage us, exasperate us, repel us, and finally bore us. 35-year old kids are no fun no matter how physically appealing or attractive they may be. And they become progressively less interesting and less tolerable the older they get. But for them, they are the world. The French may call it l'amour fou, crazy love, insane love, but to me it is simply a psychological syndrome, a sickness, and nothing really more exotic than that. It is prolonged, pathological infantilism - beautifully and "Moulin Rouge"ishly photographed, acted and edited - brought to its logical conclusion.

reviewText: The first feature from French director Yann Samuell is an "expressionistic" allegory about love, disguised as a romantic fantasy. It is about how in our relationships we never outgrow childhood games or fully recover from insecurities caused by deep childhood wounds. It is about how people in love constantly test each other. Each dare is a renewed demand for the other person to prove their love, no matter what the sacrifice."Love Me If You Dare" is a gimmick translation of "Jeux d'enfants", a better translation would be "Games of Children". But given the general confusion about this film by English speaking viewers and critics the inaccurate title is probably appropriate. Film Theory 101 would include a discussion of the two basic film extremes, realism and expressionism. Generally the closer a film comes to reproducing reality, the less room there is for the filmmaker to express his artistry. Which is not to say that realism is necessarily less manipulative than expressionism, both aim to affect their viewing audience, expressionism is just less constrained.When you are used to a steady diet of Hollywood realism, it is difficult to switch gears and watch a film like "Jeux d'enfants" without attempting to force it into the realism mold. The temptation is to gloss over the surreal elements and to take everything you see literally. But Samuell has a background as an illustrator and designer. Note the inventive visuals that employ a multitude of cardboard cutouts and idyllic fantasy settings. This is expressionism. Note the accelerated action segments and strange transitions. This is expressionism. Note the interesting time passage montages and flashbacks.While you sometimes see similar stuff incorporated into a realistic film, it is explained away as a dream, hallucination, or memory. Here it is a tip-off that this is a surreal allegory like Bunuel's "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie". If you avoid taking "Jeux d'enfants" too literally, stop being judgmental about the actions and motivations of its characters, and focus instead on picking up its allegorical elements you will probably understand it better and enjoy it more.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

reviewText: This is not a chick flick, at least not necessarily a chick flick.If you enjoy French films in the realm of Audrey Tatou, then "Love Me if You Dare," is right up your alley.First off, the U.S. title for the movie "Love Me if You Dare" is clumsily misleading from the original French title which amounts to "Children's Games."This being said, "Love Me if You Dare" is the story of two children who grow up together and form a bond not frequently seen in film or society.This film has one of those easy to spoil endings so to maintain some ambiguity I'll simply say that the film is brilliant, but the post-script style ending seems to have been tacked on to satisfy focus groups.People I talk to about this film have many very different opinions about it, one way or another, you will simply like it or you won't.
summary: Definitively French cinema, a great story, a full range of emotions.

reviewText: Leave it to the French to have a movie that twists black humor and romantic hijinks into one dark film.Even if you believe the happy ending, you must realize that no one's love could be this deep, or go this wrong.

reviewText: The excellent short story "A Perfect Day for Bananafish" by J.D. Salinger goes on one page too long. So, when I reread it. . .and I do. . .I quit the story with Sybil and Seymour coming ashore from their afternoon swim. It is true Seymour--it is his fate as the most gifted poet in the Glass family--must die. But not here.Likewise, "Love Me If You Dare (Are You Game?)" should end sooner. And, when I watch it again. . .and I plan to because, for a while it is a great movie: charming and moving at the beginning, edgy and true in the middle. . .I will stop it early into chapter 9 as the tin rolls down the church aisle. . .End it!End it! Quit this film before it, like Seymour Glass, commits suicide.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First off, don't be fooled by the romantic cover or the Amelie comparisons it gets. The first part of the movie is very touching and sweet like Amelie, but once these little rascals grow up, all hell breaks loose.I'll spare you a synopsis, but basically this is a movie about two people who I think really are in love with eachother(they form an undeniable bond as children), but don't know how to turn off  the dare button to be honest enough about their true feelings and are too insecure to be the first one to assert their love. And so, the dare game continues to some really disturbing levels. Disturbing, yes-but in a sorta "aha-top that one!" entertaining way, where you do anticipate how each will raise the bar each time. It's a sick exercise, but there you go.It's sad in a way too cause by the time they are honest enough, things are just too much of a mess by then. I watched it again for the second time, and actually the earlier parts of the film come off much more sadly because both attempt to express their feelings, but are shut down by the other's insecure responses. That part of the movie is what rings true to me actually, and so it makes the movie have a sad, regretful tone to it, even though the more sensational parts of the movie get the spotlight....

reviewText: Guillaume Canet and Marion Cotillard play Julian and Sophie.Julien is endlessly energetic and precociously brilliant, but unable to bear the heartbreak of his mother's impending death. Sohpie is wildly imaginative, mischievous and determined to be different, yet  in search of someone who'll both accept and love her. When they meet one another, everything changes. They begin what seems to be a child's momentary amusement. Soon, the game has become something far more larger and thrilling than the sad and disappointing world around them.Wonderfully acted.Side note couple are married today!! 2012
Title: N/A

reviewText: When a young polish girl is tormented in the street by her classmates 8 year old Julien hands her his gift to his ailing mother....a tin trinket...young Sophie essentially dares the poor boy into being her friend which he obliges by releasing the parking brake of the school bus sending the children who tormented her careening into traffic.The tin trinket goes back and forth with each dare through the course of their lives each one diffrent than the last some last years others seconds some are destructive others menial and embarrasing.The tone of this movie is bitter sweet with a dark and twisted ending that is morbid but romantic in a sadistic way.I initially thought the look of this movie was too simular to Amilie but the more engrossed you become in these two charactors the more you realise that this is a stand alone film worthy of much praise and admiration.Once again im stricken with disbelif when I ponder the american romantic comedy genre and its all too familuar themes of love redemption and unrealistic portrayal of people in love.There have been a scant few american love stories I can relate with in recent years High Fidelity,Punch Drunk Love and Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind are the only ones that worth recalling.Love Me if You Dare falls on my ever expanding list of must own must have romantic comedies from abroad.Great film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In the autumn of 2003, France saw the huge hit of 'Love Me If You Dare' which gathered more than 1.4 million viewers in that country.  Sadly, however, the commercial success of this film there will not mean that it will grab your heart like 'Amelie' did.  In fact, 'Love Me' is the flip side of fantasy of Amelie, and the film can be as unsettling, or even nasty at some time.First-time director Yann Samuell gives us the story about a boy and a girl, whose fates are sealed when they met on the street.  Sophie and Julien, when meeting each other for the first time, begin an apparently innocent 'game' -- game of dare -- among the uptight adults.  At first, it was just a silly prank, like upsetting a wedding party, but it soon grows more annoying to the kids' family, especially the parents of Julien.The film gets more unconventional when it goes on, showing us the two now as college students.  They still keep on the game, knowing that they cannot stay as they are forever.  And the 'game' they play become more and more dangerous and even deadly.The film makes a point, and follows its initial premise relentlessly.  That's how people say.  I disagree.  For the ending is a real disappointment.  I don't care if the couple are annoying, potential anti-hero/heroine -- Robert DeNiro did that kind role many times, and still remained a gripping presence throughout the film like 'Taxi Driver.'  To me, 'Love Me' ends too suddenly, as if the filmmaker does not how what to do with the two, and then, to make it worse, he adds another 'might be' ending (or something like that).  This is a weak conclusion that needs re-write, or at least more consistenct tone.The actors Guillaume Cane and Marion Cotillard give their best, and they are certainly good, but the child actors playing their counterparts are more plausible and convincing, making the first part of the film much stronger. Perhaps the weak second act is partly because we usually do not see adults indulging in games.The director has a flair for Tim Burton-like visuals, and the premise is interesting, but it is explored in a too monotonous way.  There are many things that could be more interesting -- like the relation between Julien and his distraught father -- but the film concentrates on the eternal boy and the girl.  Maybe that is exactly what the film wanted to do.If you dare to see something different, try this one.  You might like it, or not.
summary: Ultimate 'Game of Dare' Carried Out Throughout Your Life

reviewText: I was reluctant to watch this film at first, and let me say, I was an idiot!The movie is wonderfully directed, beautifully acted, and well written as well as creative.From the first moment when you see the very lovely Marion Cotillard, I was hooked.  It is witty, fun, and has some great metaphorical storytelling scenes that make you wonder what happened for a second, only to then realize the beauty of it.I love it.  Mind you, it is in French (with subtitles for us Americans) and no english audio track, so if you are totally against subtitles, I am sorry, but you will miss out on a character adventure that is smart and playful.I love it.
